title: [BUG] Blazor WASM NET10 -
body:
### Description

Per Microsoft Learn example: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/blazor/webassembly-native-dependencies?view=aspnetcore-10.0&utm_source=chatgpt.com

Navigate to a page with the component on it and receive error.
SkiaSharp version 3.119.2-preview.1  (also tried 3.118.0-preview.2.3 and 3.119.1)

### Code

Project file:
```xaml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk.BlazorWebAssembly">
	<PropertyGroup>
		<TargetFramework>net10.0</TargetFramework>
		<Nullable>enable</Nullable>
		<ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
		<OverrideHtmlAssetPlaceholders>true</OverrideHtmlAssetPlaceholders>
	</PropertyGroup>
	<ItemGroup>
		<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly" Version="10.0.0" />
		<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.DevServer" Version="10.0.0" PrivateAssets="all" />
		<PackageReference Include="SkiaSharp.Views.Blazor" Version="3.119.2-preview.1" />
	</ItemGroup>
</Project>
```
(same issue with release build)

Razor component:
```cs
@using SkiaSharp
@using SkiaSharp.Views.Blazor

<SKCanvasView OnPaintSurface="OnPaintSurface" IgnorePixelScaling="true" />

@code {
    private void OnPaintSurface(SKPaintSurfaceEventArgs args)
    {
        var canvas = args.Surface.Canvas;
        canvas.Clear(SkiaSharp.SKColors.White);
        using var paint = new SkiaSharp.SKPaint
        {
            Color = SkiaSharp.SKColors.Black,
            IsAntialias = true,
            Style = SkiaSharp.SKPaintStyle.Fill
        };
        using var font = new SkiaSharp.SKFont { Size = 24 };
        var coord = new SkiaSharp.SKPoint(args.Info.Width / 2, (args.Info.Height + font.Size) / 2);
        canvas.DrawText("SkiaSharp", coord, font, paint);
    }
}
```

### Expected Behavior

Display the barcode in a canvas.

### Actual Behavior

```
ManagedError: TypeInitialization_Type, SkiaSharp.SKImageInfo
```

### Version of SkiaSharp

3.118.0-preview.2 (Next Preview)

### Last Known Good Version of SkiaSharp

2.88.9 (Previous)

### IDE / Editor

Visual Studio (Windows)

### Platform / Operating System

Windows

### Platform / Operating System Version

Windows 11 Pro
VS 2026
.net 10
Edge/Chrome

### Devices

All

### Relevant Screenshots

_No response_

### Relevant Log Output

```shell

```

### Code of Conduct

- [x] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct

comments.author: github-actions[bot]
comments.body:
**Triage Summary**  

Labels will be applied to indicate the affected areas involving SkiaSharp in the Blazor application, as well as the platforms involved (WASM and UWP).

This issue does not appear to be a regression, but it does involve reliability concerns due to unexpected behavior and crashes.

Additional remarks:
* The issue is specifically related to a Blazor WebAssembly project using the SkiaSharp library, and there are no appropriate labels for Blazor or SkiaSharp technologies available.

<details>
<summary>Detailed Summary and Actions</summary>

Summary of the triage:

- The issue affects the SkiaSharp.Views.Blazor component when rendering in a Blazor application.
- The platforms impacted include WASM (via Blazor WebAssembly) and Windows Universal (UWP).
- There are noted reliability issues due to crashes or unexpected behaviors in the component integration.

Summary of the actions that will be performed:

| Action         | Item                             | Description                                                                                       |
| :------------- | :------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Apply Label    | area/SkiaSharp.Views.Blazor     | The issue specifically relates to the usage of SkiaSharp within a Blazor application.            |
| Apply Label    | os/WASM                         | The problem occurs in a Blazor WebAssembly environment, indicating a WASM-related bug.          |
| Apply Label    | os/Windows-Universal-UWP        | The issue is reported in a Windows UWP context, particularly with Visual Studio for Windows.     |
| Apply Label    | tenet/reliability               | The issue describes crashes or unexpected behavior, aligning with reliability concerns.           |

</details>



_This entire triage process was automated by AI and mistakes may have been made. Please let us know so we can continue to improve._

comments.author: NetRushJacob
comments.body: Note, it wouldn't let me clear the **Last Known Good Version of SkiaSharp**...there is no last known good version in this regard as it seems more related to .net 10 WASM projects.

comments.author: jahnotto
comments.body:
Is anyone able to use SkiaSharp with Blazor WASM .NET 10?

I'm getting this exception:

Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Rendering.WebAssemblyRenderer[100]
      Unhandled exception rendering component: libSkiaSharp
System.DllNotFoundException: libSkiaSharp
   at SkiaSharp.SKPath..ctor(9bee82eb-c257-4236-bf75-dabfa23e06de)

comments.author: Webreaper
comments.body:
Also seeing the same thing (.Net 10.0.0.1). Tried installing wasm-tools for .Net 10 but didn't help. I'm seeing this on MacOS in Rider, SkiaSharp v3.119.1.

I tried rolling back to 2.88.9 but the same issue occurs, so it's something specific to .Net 10. :(

comments.author: jahnotto
comments.body: I tried rolling back to several older versions (including 2.88.9 and 2.88.0) without luck, too.

comments.author: EngstromJimmy
comments.body:
Restoring the .NET 10 wasm workload helped me.
dotnet workload restore
I did restart my computer after, not sure if I needed to or not.

comments.author: jahnotto
comments.body:
> Restoring the .NET 10 wasm workload helped me. dotnet workload restore I did restart my computer after, not sure if I needed to or not.

Awesome -- that worked! Thank you @EngstromJimmy. I'm using the latest stable version (3.119.1).

comments.author: Webreaper
comments.body: Unfortunately, `dotnet workload restore` didn't have any effect from me - I'm still seeing the same issue on MacOS. I'm also seeing the same exceptions in a production build/deployment (i.e., not on my development machine) running on Linux.
